results.title: Putin’s Maestro, and the Limits of Cultural Exchange in Wartime
results.abstract: The Russian conductor Valery Gergiev and the diva Anna Netrebko have lost engagements because of their ties to Putin, as geopolitics and music collide once again.

multimedia.caption: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia addressed the audience via video link before Valery Gergiev conducted the Mariinsky Orchestra in the Syrian city of Palmyra in 2016.
President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia addressed the audience via video link before Valery Gergiev conducted the Mariinsky Orchestra in the Syrian city of Palmyra in 2016.

results.title: Bong Joon Ho and Ryusuke Hamaguchi on Oscar Surprise ‘Drive My Car’
results.abstract: The Korean filmmaker and the Japanese director have long admired each other. The two explain why Hamaguchi’s best-picture nominee resonates.

results.title: The Women of ‘The Dropout’ Want to Humanize Elizabeth Holmes
results.abstract: In a group interview, Elizabeth Meriwether, Amanda Seyfried and Rebecca Jarvis discuss the new Hulu series about the fall of Theranos and their efforts to reveal the woman beneath the turtleneck.

multimedia.caption: “The Dropout” tracks the rise and fall of Elizabeth Holmes and the start-up Theranos. From left: Elizabeth Meriwether, the creator; Amanda Seyfried, the star; and Rebecca Jarvis, the journalist whose podcast inspired the series.
multimedia.copyright: Jingyu Lin for The New York Times

results.title: 5 Minutes That Will Make You Love Wagner
results.abstract: Rian Johnson, Patti Smith, Alex Ross and others offer favorite highlights of a composer best known for his sprawling length.

results.title: Vladimir Potanin, Russian Oligarch, Steps Down as Guggenheim Trustee
results.abstract: Mr. Potanin, one of the richest men in Russia and a Guggenheim Museum donor for decades, is the latest oligarch affected by widening outrage over the war in Ukraine.
results.byline: By Graham Bowley and Matt Stevens

multimedia.caption: Vladimir Potanin, one of the richest men in Russia and a trustee of the Guggenheim Museum for many years, is stepping down from its board.

results.title: The State of the Union: Together, if Only for a Few Minutes
results.abstract: President Biden brought a cheerleading tone to a normal-ish address for very abnormal times.

results.title: Broadway’s Cort Theater Will Have a New Name: James Earl Jones
results.abstract: The landmark theater will be renamed in honor of the 91-year-old actor who has made 21 Broadway appearances and won two competitive Tony Awards.

results.title: Dua Lipa Brings Her Lockdown Anthems to the Arena
results.abstract: The pop star’s second album, “Future Nostalgia,” is ambitious and impressive. Onstage, the production didn’t match the LP’s ecstasy.

multimedia.caption: Dua Lipa’s “Future Nostalgia” was one of the first excellent albums of the Covid era. On Tuesday, she brought her long-delayed tour supporting it to Madison Square Garden in New York.

results.title: Gold Ingots From 18th-Century Shipwreck Returned to France
results.abstract: The Chinese ingots, illegally harvested from a French frigate that sank while returning from Nanjing, were seized by U.S. investigators when they were put up for auction in California.

multimedia.caption: A special agent with U.S. Homeland Security Investigations holding two of the five gold ingots that were returned to France.
A special agent with U.S. Homeland Security Investigations holding two of the five gold ingots that were returned to France.

results.title: Gaming Giant Behind Fortnite Buys Bandcamp, an Indie Music Haven
results.abstract: Epic Games is acquiring an online music platform that has been embraced by musicians for its eclectic offerings and a payment system that favors artists.

results.title: Barry Bauman, Restoration Artist and Detective, Dies at 73
results.abstract: A noted conservator, he peeled back paintings’ hidden layers and sometimes uncovered fakes, most notably a portrait wrongly thought to be of Mary Todd Lincoln.

multimedia.caption: The art conservator Barry Bauman in 2014. Over the course of his career he brought numerous faded canvases back to their former glory.

results.title: Shirley Hughes, Whose Books Depicted Children’s Mini-Dramas, Dies at 94
results.abstract: Beloved in her native England, she wrote and illustrated more than 70 books for children of all ages, with millions of copies sold worldwide. She was honored by the queen.

multimedia.caption: Shirley Hughes in 1982. She believed that children should be allowed to be bored and not pressured to read. “It’s not a competition,” she said, “though you’d think it was the way some parents go on.”
multimedia.copyright: Susan Debra Windmiller/Fairfax Media via Getty Images)

multimedia.caption: Shirley Hughes in 1982. She believed that children should be allowed to be bored and not pressured to read. “It’s not a competition,” she said, “though you’d think it was the way some parents go on.”

results.title: NoViolet Bulawayo Believes Freedom Begins With Imagination
results.abstract: For her 2013 debut novel, Bulawayo was the first Black woman from Africa to become a finalist for the Booker Prize. Her new novel, “Glory,” is a story about a nation on the cusp of revolution.

multimedia.caption: NoViolet Bulawayo wrote her new novel after Robert Mugabe, Zimbabwe’s longtime president, was deposed. “Writing it felt like responding to a call of duty,” she said.
multimedia.copyright: Zinyange Auntony for The New York Times

results.abstract: The novelist Kathryn Davis’s personal and time-shuffling new book, “Aurelia, Aurélia,” is about the death of her husband.

results.title: Michele McNally, Who Elevated Times Photography, Dies at 66
results.abstract: The paper won six Pulitzer Prizes for photography during her tenure as its director of photography and a member of the newsroom’s top management.

results.title: Sharon Wohlmuth, Photographer of Best-Selling ‘Sisters,’ Dies at 75
results.abstract: Her images, paired with the words of Carol Saline, created a publishing sensation that led to the follow-up books “Mothers & Daughters” and “Best Friends.”

multimedia.caption: Sharon Wohlmuth at an exhibition of her work in 2009. Major publishers declined to take on her “Sisters” project, which became a best-seller.
